g.text: WHAT IS ALREADY KNOWN ABOUT THIS SUBJECT

We conducted a systematic review and performed a meta-analysis to clarify the role of
Subgroup analyses were performed by: (i) region of origin, (ii) study type, and (iii) genotyping. We evaluated the risk for
slow-acetylator alleles were associated with a higher risk of AT-DILI, especially in West Asian TB patient popula-
tions, but not in European and African populations.
acetylators, the risk was highest for
Tuberculosis (TB) is a major global public health problem. In
2015, there were an estimated 10.4 million new (incident) TB
known to commonly lead to adverse drug reactions (ADRs)
such as hepatotoxicity, gastrointestinal disorders, allergic
reactions, arthralgia and neurological disorders [2, 3], the most
common ADR during anti-TB treatment leading to drug
discontinuation in 11% of patients [4]. Isoniazid is a key drug
in anti-TB therapy but is also the key drug responsible for the
occurrence of drug-induced liver injury during anti-TB treat-
oral isoniazid treatment at 300 mg once daily [5]. The
metabolic intermediates of isoniazid appear to be the cause of
hepatotoxicity [6]. In the liver, isoniazid is
hydrazine and acetyl-hydrazine are two metabolites of isonia-
zid, which are primarily involved in the mechanism of
rst genetic variation in drug response ever discov-
was later found to be induced mainly by the polymorphisms
of previous studies have assessed the association between
gene polymorphism and the AT-DILI. The results of
the studies were inconsistent, mainly due to limited power,
Therefore, personalized dosing has not yet been introduced
in programmatic anti-TB treatment. However, considering
rence of AT-DILI, we aimed to systematically review and
meta-analyse all published studies designed to assess the
presence and strength of the postulated genetic associations
The details of the systematic review and meta-analysis were
registered in the PROSPERO register (registration number
Two authors (M.Z. and S.W.) independently searched the
PubMed, Medline and EMBASE databases for studies on the
polymorphisms with risk of DILI up to
